chapter.htmlHeader: Scenario: Suspected ankylosing spondylitis
chapter.summary: Covers the initial management of suspected ankylosing spondylitis in primary care, when to refer, and what advice to give.
chapter.htmlStringContent: From age 16 years onwards.

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.htmlHeader: What advice should I give a person with suspected ankylosing spondylitis?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Advise that diagnosis of ankylosing spondylitis can be difficult and referral to a rheumatologist is required for confirmation.
    • Clinical features and diagnostic tests for ankylosing spondylitis can help make the diagnosis, but no symptom, sign, or test result in isolation is useful for diagnosis. The rheumatologist may arrange blood tests and x-rays (and MRI if there are no x-ray changes). For more information, see Investigations in the section on Diagnosis.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
Advice for people with suspected ankylosing spondylitis

This recommendation is based on the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence guideline Spondyloarthritis in over 16s: diagnosis and managment [NICE, 2017a; NICE, 2017b].

  • Axial spondyloarthritis is difficult to diagnose without specialist assessment [NICE, 2018] and should not be ruled out solely on the presence or absence of any individual sign, symptom, or test result [NICE, 2017a].

subChapters.htmlHeader: What treatment should I start for someone with suspected ankylosing spondylitis while waiting for referral?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Consider prescribing a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) while waiting for referral. Take account of the person's risk of serious adverse effects, the safety profiles of individual standard NSAIDs or coxibs, the person's ability to tolerate individual NSAIDs, their other medications, and their preferences. 
    • To minimise the risks of long-term NSAIDs, use the lowest effective dose.
    • Monitor risk factors and consider the use of gastroprotective treatment.
      • If the person is at increased risk of cardiovascular, renal, or gastrointestinal (GI) adverse effects, see the CKS topic on NSAIDs - prescribing issues for more information on prescribing NSAIDs, including gastroprotection.
    • If an NSAID taken at the maximum tolerated dose for 2–4 weeks does not provide adequate pain relief, consider switching to another NSAID. 
  • If NSAIDs are contraindicated, consider prescribing a standard analgesic (for example paracetamol with or without codeine). Note that non-NSAID analgesics will not control inflammation.
    • For more information, see the CKS topic on Analgesia - mild-to-moderate pain.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs)
  • This recommendation is consistent with the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) guideline Spondyloarthritis in over 16s: diagnosis and managment [NICE, 2017a] and also reflects ASAS-EULAR recommendations for axial spondyloarthritis [van der Heijde et al, 2017], and advice from the American College of Rheumatology [Ward et al, 2016], and the Canadian Rheumatology Association [Rohekar et al, 2015]. NSAIDs can be initiated in primary care before confirmation of the diagnosis of spondyloarthritis [McAllister et al, 2017]. 
    • NSAIDs are particularly useful in people with axial spondyloarthritis, with benefit seen in terms of pain reduction with most NSAIDs. There is debate as to whether NSAIDs modify radiological progression in axial inflammation when a person has raised inflammatory markers [NICE, 2017b]. 
  • A Cochrane systematic review (search date June 2014) found 39 studies (n = 4356) on NSAID use in people with axial spondyloarthritis, although no trials included in the meta-analyses assessed people with non-radiographic axial spondyloarthritis. The findings were [Kroon et al, 2015]: 
    • Better pain relief with NSAIDs compared with placebo with a 16.5 points lower visual analogue score in the NSAID group (high quality evidence, n = 850, 95% CI –20.8 to –12.2, number needed to treat [NNT] = 4).
    • Improved disease activity with NSAIDs compared with placebo (moderate quality evidence, n = 190, 17.5 points lower disease activity index score in the NSAID group, 95% CI –23.1 to –11.8, NNT = 3).
    • Improved function with NSAIDs compared with placebo (high quality evidence, n = 356, 9.1 points lower functional index score in the NSAID group, 95% CI –13.0 to –5.1, NNT = 5).
    • No significant difference in adverse effects between the NSAID and placebo groups after 12 weeks (moderate and low quality evidence).
    • Equal effectiveness between NSAID classes in terms of benefits or harms.
  • NICE and the American College of Rheumatology do not recommend a preferred NSAID [Ward et al, 2016; NICE, 2017a] and there is no clear difference in the effectiveness of NSAIDs [Taurog et al, 2016; Sieper and Poddubnyy, 2017]. 
  • The NICE guideline development group noted that comorbidities influence the choice of NSAID [NICE, 2017b]. Cardiovascular, gastrointestinal, and renal risks of NSAIDs should be considered when prescribing [Kroon et al, 2015]. 
Paracetamol and other analgesics
  • This recommendation is based on the ASAS-EULAR and Canadian management recommendations for spondyloarthritis which, despite a lack of formal evidence, suggest analgesics (for example paracetamol and opioid-[like] drugs) might be considered for residual pain if other recommended treatments are contraindicated, poorly tolerated, or have failed [Rohekar et al, 2015; van der Heijde et al, 2017].

subChapters.htmlHeader: When should I refer a person with suspected ankylosing spondylitis?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Refer to rheumatology for a spondyloarthritis assessment if a person has low back pain starting before the age of 45 years and lasting longer than 3 months, plus four or more of the following criteria:
    • Low back pain starting before the age of 35 years.
    • Symptoms which wake them during the second half of the night.
    • Buttock pain.
    • Improvement when moving.
    • Improvement within 48 hours of taking a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID).
    • Spondyloarthritis in a first-degree relative.
    • Current or past arthritis.
    • Current or past enthesitis.
    • Current or past psoriasis.
  • If exactly 3 of the additional criteria are present, perform an HLA-B27 test. If the test is positive, refer the person to a rheumatologist for a spondyloarthritis assessment.
  • If axial spondyloarthritis is suspected, but the person does not meet the criteria for referral, advise them to return for further assessment if they develop new signs, symptoms, or risk factors (particularly if there is a history of current or past inflammatory bowel disease, psoriasis, or uveitis).
  • Refer urgently (same day) to ophthalmology if anterior uveitis (iritis) is suspected.
    • Suspect acute anterior uveitis when an eye becomes red and acutely painful especially if there is also photophobia or blurred vision.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
This recommendation reflects the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) guidance Spondyloarthritis in over 16s: diagnosis and management which outlines criteria for referral to a rheumatologist for a spondyloarthritis assessment based on symptoms and previous and family history [NICE, 2017a].

  • The NICE guideline development group noted that individual signs, symptoms, and risk factors alone may not be sufficient to warrant referral or make an accurate diagnosis [NICE, 2017b]. Prompt diagnosis is important as delays in confirming spondyloarthritis can cause significant morbidity. Specialist referral can reduce the delay in diagnosis and improve access to appropriate treatment and outcomes [NICE, 2018].
  • Axial spondyloarthritis is difficult to diagnose without specialist assessment [NICE, 2018] and experts agree that axial spondyloarthritis is usually diagnosed and its management coordinated by rheumatologists as it requires multidisciplinary management [Taurog et al, 2016; van der Heijde et al, 2017]. 
  • Referral to rheumatology of suspected cases of ankylosing spondylitis will allow the rheumatologist to [Ward et al, 2016; NICE, 2017a; van der Heijde et al, 2017]: 
    • Confirm the diagnosis.
    • Review current treatment including any need for biological DMARDs.
    • Refer to physiotherapy for an individualised, structured exercise programme, including stretching, strengthening and postural exercises and range of motion exercises for the lumbar, thoracic, and cervical spine.
    • Refer to a specialist therapist (for example occupational therapy or physiotherapy) if the person has difficulty with activities of daily living for an assessment and advice on physical aids.
    • Arrange regular osteoporosis assessments (every 2 years).
    • Make arrangements for follow up and monitoring, which may be a shared care arrangement.
  • The NICE guideline development group also acknowledged the need for urgent ophthalmological assessment of people presenting with anterior uveitis in order to prevent potential sight damage [NICE, 2017b].
